comments.raw_text:
Fenix is updating their dependencies again and are starting to get ahead of us by several versions.  I'm not sure what sort of problems this might cause but we should look into updating Glean to potentially take advantage of fixes and/or address any issues that crop up.

Link to Fenix PR updating dependencies [here](https://github.com/mozilla-mobile/fenix/pull/10806/files)

Created attachment 9152509

comments.creator: alessio.placitelli@gmail.com
comments.author: alessio.placitelli@gmail.com
comments.text:
(In reply to Travis Long [:travis_] from comment #0)
> Fenix is updating their dependencies again and are starting to get ahead of us by several versions. 

I don't think we should lock on their update schedule, unless there's a good, shared reason on why we should do that.
We should really target A-C versions (something we've been trying to do, but failed to in a systematic way), since that's the common denominator to all of our projects.

> I'm not sure what sort of problems this might cause but we should look into updating Glean to potentially take advantage of fixes and/or address any issues that crop up.

AFAIK, the version the application uses dictates what ends up being used. So if Fenix uses the newer versions, that's what we'll end up using when running in Fenix.

We should still support working with whatever A-C defaults to, because those are the recommended versions that A-C consumers should use.

> I'm not sure what sort of problems this might cause but we should look into updating Glean to potentially take advantage of fixes and/or address any issues that crop up.

AFAIK, the version the application uses dictates what ends up being used. So if Fenix uses the newer versions, that's what we'll end up using when running in Fenix.

comments.author: tlong@mozilla.com
comments.text:
> AFAIK, the version the application uses dictates what ends up being used. So if Fenix uses the newer versions, that's what we'll end up using when running in Fenix.

If the application dictates the version that is ultimately used, then what's the point of _ever_ updating?

> We should still support working with whatever A-C defaults to, because those are the recommended versions that A-C consumers should use.

I'm fine with this, the only thing that Fenix is ahead of A-C on is the coroutines dependency, and only by minor version.  I can update the PR to downgrade to match A-C if you like.

comments.author: alessio.placitelli@gmail.com
comments.text:
(In reply to Travis Long [:travis_] from comment #4)
> > AFAIK, the version the application uses dictates what ends up being used. So if Fenix uses the newer versions, that's what we'll end up using when running in Fenix.
> 
> If the application dictates the version that is ultimately used, then what's the point of _ever_ updating?

For making sure our own code runs and tests with the versions we're sure will be used, at the minimum. I believe there's some compatibility logic taking place when deciding what version to use, at the end of the chain.

> > We should still support working with whatever A-C defaults to, because those are the recommended versions that A-C consumers should use.
> 
> I'm fine with this, the only thing that Fenix is ahead of A-C on is the coroutines dependency, and only by minor version.  I can update the PR to downgrade to match A-C if you like.

Yes, let's match A-C, please
